U'e need not be greatly surprised‚ therefore, to learn that on returning to the Fatherland in 1503, Mutian accepted, without hesitation, a canonry at Gotha. Here, inscribing “Beata 'l'ranquillitas’' above his study door, he resolved to spend the rest of his days in learned leisure. Other preferments were proffered the reclnse from time to time, but were invariably declined: his income sufficed to provide him with books, and he sought for nothing beyond them. Nevertheless, natural indolence, or a contempt for the opinion of the world, led Mutian to seek no literary renown. He has left no writings behind him, save his letters.l and, to jndge from internal evidence, we may well doubt whether these were intended for publication.

Before long, however, the “blessed peace '³ of Gotha began to pall upon the gregarious Mutian. Society there was doubtless as dull as it was limited, and a scholar who does not write must converse. F ortunately his old university was scarce twenty miles away, and Mutian began to betake himself thither, often for considerable periods,

At Erfurt 116 speedily made himself the centre of a congenial circle. A band of young and ardent humanists had thither congregated: their aspirations were lofty but vague, and needed but the guidance of a leader of riper years and experience to burst the last bonds of scholastice tradition, and take their places in the forefront of the army of light.
